text.body:
rain
Chap. 2
As soon as morning dawned I crept from
my assylum to that I might view the
adjacent cottage and discover if I could
remain in the kennel that I had found.
It was situated
at
^
against
the back of the cottage
and
^
surrounded
on
its
^
the
open
the
sides which were exposed
by a pigstye & –c r l ear pool of water one
part was open and by that I had crept
in but now with stones and wood I cover
ed every crevice with stones & wood by which I might be
discovered ^
yet in such a manner
that I could move the n m
on an occasion
to pass out; all the light I enjoyed came
through the stye and that was suffi
cient for me.
Having thus arranged my dwelling &
spr carpeted it with clean straw, I retired
for I saw the figure of a man
in
at
a distance
and I feared remembered
but
too well my treatment the night
before not to trust myself in his
power. I had first however provided
for my sustenance for that day by mean
by a loaf of bro coarse bread which I pur
loined and a cup
w by
with
which I could take
drin g k
more conveniently than from my
hand
and
of the pure water which flowed by my
house retreat – but
t T he f
l oor of that being
was a little raised
it
^
so that it was kept
^
perfectly
dry and by
its vicinity to the chimney of the
kitchen fire of the cottage it was
tolerably warm.
And
b B eing thus provided
I determined to reside in this hovel
untill o something should occur which
might alter my determination. It
was indeed a paradise compared to
the blea c k forest, my former residence,
and the
ir rain dropping
leaves
^
branches
^
& the dank earth
. I ate
my breakfast with pleasure and was
about to remove a plank to procure
myself a little water when I heard
a step and looking through a small
chink a beheld a young creature
with a pail on her head passing
before my hovel. The girl was youn
g
and of gentle demænour unlike what
I have since found Cottagers and farm
house servants to be – Yet she was mean
ly dressed – a blue coarse
^
blue
petticoat and a
linen jacket being her only garb on her fair hair
was plaited but not adorned; she looked patient
yet sad. She passed aw away but in a quarter
of an hour returned, be bearing the pail which
was now partly filled with milk. As she walked
along seemingly incommoded by the burthen
a young man met her whose countenance
expressed a deeper desponc
e ns des ces ly; than her
uttering a few
words
sounds
with ain an air of
melancholy he took the pail from her head
and bore it into the cottage himself. She
followed wiping dry my her tears whi , and they
diasppeared – Presently I saw the young man
again with some tools in his hand cross the
field opposite the cottage and the girl was
also busied someti n m es in and som the cottage
and sometimes in the yard where she fe t d
some ck chickens. and after some hours While
I examined my dwelling I discovered that part
of the cottage window had formerly occupied
a corner of it pu but the panes had n been
filled up with wood. In one of these was
a small & allmost imperceptible h chink,
through which
howev the eye could just
pene a t rate;
and looking in I behe sa w
thro this chink
a
small room was visible,
whitewashed
^
&
clean but very
bare of furniture & in co one corner near
a small fire I saw
^
beheld
sate
an old man sitting leaning
his head on his hand – in a disconslate atti
tude — X
his hair
was grey
The young girl was co occupied in
arranging the cottage and
but presently
when that was
done she took somthing out of the a drawer
which employed her hands
and
^
& sat down beside the o
the old
man who taking up an instur instrument began
to play and to produce sounds sweeter than
the voice of the thrush or nightingale. This chapter is too short
It was a lovely sight even to me poor
whec wretch who had never beheld aught
beautiful before.
his
the
silver hairs &
benevolent countenance
^
of
the more aged inhabit cottager
won my reverence
while
^
the
gentle manners of the girl enticed
my love. He played a sweet mournful
air which I percieved drew tears from
the eyes of
the gen amiable gir l
^
his
you amiable companion
till her
of which the old man took
^
no
notice of it untill
she sobbed audibly – He the then pronounced
a few sounds and the poor creature leaving
her work knelt at his feet he rasied her
and smiled with such grace kindness &
love that I felt my own hard nerves
move and I was obliged to withdraw from
nature they were a
nature
mixture of pain & pleasure; such as I had never experienced
my the hole. Presently the young ma
either from the hunger or cold,
orfrom or warmth or food and I
withdrew
from my station
withdrew
unable to
bear
these new
these
emotio
ns
emotions
Soon after this the young man returned
bearing on his sholders a load load of wood
the r girl met him at the door & helped
to relieve him of his burden and took
taking some of it into the fire cottage
placed it on the fire;
& then she and the
youth went apart into a
nok
nook
of the cottage
and he shewed her a large loaf and a piece
of cheese
.— She seemed pleased and went
into the garden for soome roots & plants
which she placed in water and then upon
the fire–. She
then
afterwards
continued her work
&
whilst
the young man went into the pa garden
and appeared busily employed in digging & pul
pulling up roots– –After he had been employed
thus about hal an hour the young woman
joined him, & they returned to the cottage
together – The old man in the mean time
had been pe
^
n sive but on the approach
of
the others
^
his companions
he assumed a
pen
more
cheerful
air, and they sat down to eat. They quickly
finished the
ir meal
^
was quickly dispatched;
the young woman was
again occupied in arranging the cottage the
old man walked before the door in the
sun for a few minutes
, leaning on the arm of the you ng th
man
Nothing could exceed in beauty the contrast
between these two love excl excellent
creatures One was old, with silver hairs
and a countenance beaming with bene
volence & love; the younger was sli
m
ght
and graceful in his fu figure and
his feautures were moulded with the
finest
simetry symmetry – yet his eyes & attitude
expressed the utmost sadness and despon
dencency— The old man returned to the
cottage; and the youth with tools different
from those which he had used in the morning,
directed his steps across the fields– Night
quickly shut in but to my extreme won
der I found that the cottagers had a
means of prolonging light by the use of tapers
and was pleased to find that end setting
of the sun did not put an end I had to
the pleasure I experienced in watching
the
my human neighbours . –In the evening
the young girl and her companion
were employed in various occupations;
that
which I did not then understand, & the
old man again took that instru
ment which produced th o e se
divine
sounds that had enchanted me in
the morning.
and
w W hen
So soon as
he had finish
-ed the youth began,– not to play , – but
he
to
utter ed sounds which were monoto
nous and and
far from
neither resembling
the harmony
of the old mans instrument or the
songs of the birds I since found that
he read aloud , but at that time I knew nothing of the
science of words or letters. a
t that
time . The family soon extinguished
their lights and retired, as I conjectured,
to sleep . rest
I lay on my straw but I could not
sleep – I thought of the occurences of
the day.– What cheifly struck me was
the gentle manners of these people, and
I longed to join them but dared not.—
I remembered too well the treatment I
had suffered the night before fro
n
m
the barbarous villagers and resolved
whatever I should
^
course of conduct I might
afterwards think it
hereafter consider
right to do
it proper to pursue that for the present I would
remain quietly in my hovel watching
and endeavouring to discover the motive
of their motions actions.—
The
y
^
cottagers arose the next morning before
the sun;– The young woman arranged the
cottage & per prepared the food; & the
youth mounted on a large strange animal
road rode away. This day was passed in
the same routine
and
as
the preceeding one.
The young young man was constantly
employed out of doors and the girl in
various laborious occupations within.
.
— The old
man whom I soon perceived to be blind
employed his leisure hours in playing
on his instrument or in pesively
contemplation – Nothing could exceed
the love & respect that the younger
cottagers
bore shewed
towards this venerable
old man – They performed towards
^
him
every
little office of
love affection & duty with gentleness;
and he rewarded them by his benevo
lent smiles. B
They were not however entirely
happy–The youth young er man
d & his
companion, often retired into a corner
of their common room and wept. I saw
no cause for this unhappiness but
I was deeply affected by it – If such
lovely creatures were miserable it was
less strange that alone' d I, an imperfect
and solitary being should be wretched—
yet why were these gentle beings un
happy – they poss
^
ess ed a delightful house
for such
^
it
was
it to
in
my eyes) and every
luxury. they had a fire to warm
them when chill and delicious viands
when hungry– they were dressed
in clothes that kept t in excel
lent clothes and still more they enjoy
ed one anothers company & speech
— and saw
interchanged
each day looks of affection & kindness–
What did their tears mean? Did they
really express pain? I was at first
unable to solve these questions but
perpetual attention and time
explained to me many of the appear
ances which at first
